title: Update regarding FinCorp
story_body:
Industry-Wide Shortages of High-Performance Computing Components Exacerbate Supply Chain Disruption, FinCorp Among Those Impacted

The ongoing shortages of high-performance computing components, particularly GPUs and FPGAs, have significantly impacted the financial sector, with FinCorp (FIN) being among the affected institutions. The dearth of these critical components has resulted in protracted lead times, increased costs, and reduced system performance, ultimately hindering the sector's ability to maintain optimal trading and risk management operations.

At the heart of the issue lies the scarcity of 7nm and 5nm semiconductor fabrication capacity, which has constrained the production of high-performance computing components. The lack of these components has, in turn, affected the deployment of FinCorp's high-frequency trading platforms, which rely heavily on NVIDIA's V100 and A100 GPUs to facilitate rapid trade execution and risk assessment.

Furthermore, the shortage of Xilinx's Virtex UltraScale+ FPGAs has impacted FinCorp's ability to upgrade its derivatives pricing and risk management systems, which utilize these FPGAs to accelerate complex financial modeling and simulation workloads. The resulting delays have compromised the institution's ability to maintain a competitive edge in the market.

The industry-wide nature of the shortage has been underscored by similar challenges faced by other financial institutions, including Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase. The sector's reliance on high-performance computing components has created a perfect storm, with the shortage of these components having a ripple effect throughout the financial ecosystem.

As the shortage persists, FinCorp and its peers are being forced to explore alternative architectures and technologies, including the use of ASICs and cloud-based services, to mitigate the impact of the shortage. However, these stopgap measures are unlikely to fully alleviate the disruption, and the sector will likely continue to feel the effects of the shortage until fabrication capacity is increased and component supply chains are restored.
